WebSphere administration tips

From \\"AS/400 WebSphere overview\\" by Jim Mason, president of Cape Cod Bay
Systems, which originally appeared in the May/June edition of AS/400 Experts
Journal, Vol. 3, No. 3. Provided courtesy of The 400 Group
(http://www.the400group.com).


WebSphere Advanced edition is installed in separate directories from WebSphere
Standard edition on the AS/400, and both can reside on the same AS/400.

You must be aware of the compatibility between different levels of OS/400, Java
and WebSphere and your web applications to run your e-business environment. A
given version of WebSphere will provide runtime support for servlets at a
specific API level that may not match the level you used to develop and test the
servlets with another tool like VisualAge for Java. Currently, WebSphere
Application Server Advanced Edition 3.0 can only be run with the JDK 1.1.7.

Also, it is important to remain current with PTF levels. In addition, you can
see significant benefits for both performance and application function to run on
the latest version of OS/400. It is rare that older applications have problems
running in newer WebSphere environments.

Remember, on AS/400 you can run multiple web servers with WebSphere concurrently
if you need to. Each web server has to have a unique named instance and runs on
a specified TCP port. Usually the default production server uses the default TCP
ports 80 and 443 for HTTP and HTTPS. To access other web servers, the URL from
the client browser must specify the proper port for access (for example,
http://localhost:12001/servlet/MyServlet). Therefore, you may want to
dynamically specify port numbers at runtime for your web pages rather than hard
code them. Servlets handle this very nicely, since they can output a web page
definition dynamically. The commands WRKHTTPFCFG, STRTCPSVR SERVER(*HTTP)
INSTANCE(<http instance>), ENDTCPSVR SERVER(*HTTP) INSTANCE( <http instance>)
allow you to manage the HTTP server. To administer the HTTP server, use
STRTCPSVR SERVER(*HTTP) INSTANCE( *ADMIN). Use NET *STAT CONN to see current TCP
ports in use.

The bootstrap.properties configuration file determines how WebSphere is started
with an HTTP server on your AS/400. You may need to edit the entries in this
file especially if you have servlet chains implemented with their threading
options for responses.

The /QIBM/ProdData/IBMWebAS/servlets/ directory is the default directory from
which WebSphere automatically loads servlets. Servlets in this directory can be
invoked by class name. Jar and zip files are automatically searched for classes.
In addition, you can configure the servlets.properties file for WebSphere to
point to other directories where WebSphere should automatically load servlets
and JSPs from. Servlets found elsewhere on the normal Java classpath are loaded
only once when WebSphere starts and not automatically reloaded.

Use the servlets properties file to configure: other directories to load
servlets from, alias names for servlets and initial arguments passed to servlets
when they are loaded.
